Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Evolution of Specialized Teeth and Jaws in Early Mesozoic Ray-Finned Fishes and Their Impact on Widespread Niche Differentiation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ray-finned fishes (e.g., trout, clownfish, seahorse, bass) are the most diverse group of vertebrates on Earth today and display a vast array of physical differences with regard to body shape, skull and jaw morphology, and tooth specializations. Ray-finned fishes have a long evolutionary history, and this study focuses on two extinct groups of fishes that lived during the Early Mesozoic (250-190 million years ago): the disc-shaped, deep-bodied dapediids and the torpedo-shaped, primitive redfieldiids. These two groups of fishes provide an ideal contrast (e.g., deep body versus narrow body, differences in jaws) for testing hypotheses of the impact of specialization of tooth and jaw anatomy and morphology. The researches will compare this body shape contrast with the diet, habitat preference, behavior, and niche specialization of the fish. The project will study fossils from the Early Mesozoic, a volatile time in Earth's history with global tectonic events changing the geography of the planet and shaping the diversity of organisms in different ecosystems. This research will increase our understanding of how these two groups of extinct fishes have adapted to occupy different ecological spaces and exploit different food sources.


The research will utilize state-of-the-art two- and three-dimensional digital imaging techniques, such as micro-computed tomography (CT) scanning. These tools will measure jaw and cranial anatomy and morphology as well as tooth microwear, in well-preserved redfieldiid and dapediid fossils. Using these data the investigators of this project will be able to address hypotheses about how tooth and jaw morphology relate to ecological niche space and evolutionary history. This project will provide graduate and undergraduate training in morphological and morphometric techniques, and data obtained from this study will be catalogued in online data repositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ray-finned fishes have a long evolutionary history, with many periods that remain poorly understood and understudied. This study focused on two extinct groups of fishes that lived during the Early Mesozoic (250–190 million years ago): the disc-shaped, deep-bodied fishes of the order †Dapediiformes, and the torpedo-shaped fishes of the order †Redfieldiiformes. These two groups of fishes provide an ideal contrast (e.g., deep body versus narrow body, differences in jaws) for testing hypotheses of the impact of specialization of tooth and jaw anatomy and morphology on diversification of fishes in the early Mesozoic, specifically with regard to occupying new ecological niches.

Hundreds of specimens of fossil fishes within †Redfieldiiformes and †Dapediiformes were examined, as well as closely-related ray-finned fishes. Changes to the anatomy and morphology of jaws, teeth, snout, and skull of fossil fishes that were within the scope of this project were observed and measured. State-of-the-art two- and three-dimensional visualization techniques, such as micro-computed tomography (CT) scanning and fluorescence, were used to examine fine details of the skull and jaw in redfieldiiform and dapediiform fishes. 

Work for this project, both in the field and in several museum collections, yielded data for dozens of species, as well as the discovery of a new species of redfieldiiform fish hidden among unidentified remains in a museum collection. This new species was preserved in three-dimensions, whereas most fossil fish specimens are flattened during fossilization; this allowed the examination of details that have never been seen in this group, providing key insight into the anatomy of redfieldiiform fishes. This specimen also turned out to be the oldest known representative of redfieldiiform fishes in North America, providing key information regarding biogeographic patterns and distribution of redfieldiiform fishes in the early Mesozoic.

Overall, this project produced the most comprehensive hypotheses of evolutionary relationships of each respective group. For example, this study reexamined an enigmatic taxon, †Hemicalypterus weiri, which is hypothesized by the student PI of this project to be the oldest known herbivorous fish, based on its unusual tooth morphology. The phylogenetic analysis performed in this study confirmed that †Hemicalypterus belongs within the †Dapediiformes, and is closely related to another deep-bodied fish (†Sargodon) with specialized dentition and reduced body scales. This study suggests that the evolution of herbivory in this group is related to body scale reduction as well as specialized dentition.

The results of this project have thus far been reported at six scientific conferences, two invited lectures for the broader public, and published in three scientific journals. Multiple individuals, including undergraduate students and museum volunteers, were trained by the student PI of this grant on field collection methods, basics of fish anatomy, and fossil identification and preparation. The data that was collected during this project will continue to yield new discoveries and hypotheses for years to come.
